justification: The article notes that “Variations of this experiment are widely used to measure social preferences… (Forsythe et al., 1994).”
The same sentence states that Dictator-Game variations are used to measure “attitudes towards others.”
The paper reports that Casari & Cason (2009) found different levels of “trustworthiness when using the strategy method,” implying this method is employed to capture the construct.
The comparison with the strategy method indicates that the “direct-response method” is another procedure for measuring trust-related behavior.

It states that researchers who want to measure “how much time participants spend on-screen versus off-screen (a crucial metric of participant attention and engagement) can supplement … with TaskMaster.”
The article suggests that those studying “dynamic cognitive processes” can add “a tool that captures mouse cursor trajectories” to obtain this measure.
